metadata.title: Emphysema
anatomical location body part affected: The interalveolar septa of the lungs,(1) distal to the terminal bronchioles(29)
description: Emphysema is defined pathologically as permanent enlargement of air spaces distal to terminal bronchioles accompanied by destruction of their walls(29)

Major organizations (e.g., American Thoracic Society, European Respiratory Society, and Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease [GOLD]) recognize emphysema as one of two diseases included within the term chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), the other being chronic bronchitis. There are organizations that include several other diseases under this term as well. COPD refers to a disease process that blocks or obstructs the passage of air through the lungs over time
Recent literature suggests that COPD only partially overlaps with emphysema.(29) Emphysema in the absence of COPD is increasingly recognized(29)

There are three main morphological subtypes of emphysema.(1)Classification into these subtypes typically occurs at autopsy.(29) There is no universally accepted classification system based on in vivo assessment(29) –Centriacinar (centrilobular) -Starts in respiratory bronchioles and spreads outward -Primarily affects the upper half of the lungs -This type is associated with an extended history of cigarette smoking –Panacinar (panlobular) -Affects the whole alveolus in a uniform manner -Primarily affects the lower half of the lungs -This type is often seen in patients with homozygous alpha1-antitrypsin  (AAT) deficiency –Paraseptal -Generally affects the distal airway structures, alveolar ducts, and alveolar sacs -Disease is largely confined to the septa of the lungs or pleura -Airflow typically is intact -Spontaneous pneumothorax may occur as a result of the apical bullae -Giant bullae may lead to significant compression of adjacent lung tissue -This type is associated with an extended history of cigarette smoking and homozygous alpha1-antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency

J43.J43.0: MacLeod’s syndrome, unilateral: emphysema, transparency of lung
J43.J43.9: emphysema, unspecified: emphysema (lung), (pulmonary): NOS, bullous, vesicular; emphysematous bleb

J44.J44.0: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with acute lower respiratory infection
J44.J44.1: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with acute exacerbation, unspecified
J44.J44.8: other specified chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

ICD-10 codes.J68.4: chronic respiratory conditions due to chemicals, gases, fumes, and vapors
ICD-10 codes.T65.2: toxic effect of tobacco and nicotine (ICD codes are provided for reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Initially those affected will experience dyspnea on exertion; later in the disease course they will experience dyspnea at rest(2)
Tachypnea is common, in conjunction with prolonged expiration(2)
Increased accessory muscle use to aid respiration is typical(1)
Wheezing may occur, particularly during exacerbations or exertion(2)
Early on, cough is uncommon; however, a cough later in the disease course (with scanty sputum) often is observed(2)
The patient generally appears thin and may have a barrel chest deformity(1)
Later in the disease course cardiac complications (e.g., enlargement of ventricles) often arise(2) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Chronic irritation caused by inhaled substances, typically cigarette smoke
pathogenesis: Emphysema results from the destruction of alveoli and bronchioles(1)–The walls of alveoli are weakened or destroyed in patients with emphysema. If overstretching occurs and the alveolirupture, gas exchange will be impaired(1)–Reduced tissue elasticity also causes “air trapping” within the lungs(1)
risk factors: Passive smoking at home and work (5)
Long-term  air pollution exposure and living close to busy roads (6)
Genetic factors explain a significant portion of the susceptibility(31)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with emphysema may be very short of breath and will fatigue much faster at lower levels of exertion than individuals without emphysema; thus, precautions include frequent rest breaks and modifications to activity and activity levels. Some patients may need supplemental oxygen and should be monitored for adequate oxygen levels via frequent pulse oximetry readings. If the patient still smokes or is exposed to environmental or chemical pollutants, lifestyle changes will be warranted(1)

Precautions pertaining to medication use(1) Weight gain, diabetes, and osteoporosis with long-term  corticosteroid use  Excessive use of beta-agonists  and sympathomimetics can be dangerous, especially in patients with cardiovascular disease or hypertension
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Etiology of illness -Does the patient have a history of smoking? -When did symptoms begin? -When was diagnosis of emphysema made?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Supplemental oxygen to compensate for low blood oxygen level. Frequently used to increase overall capacity for physical activity(1) Surgical options Surgery may be considered in patients who are severely symptomatic and fail to improve with medical treatment including pulmonary rehabilitation. Stable abstinence from cigarette smoking is usually mandatory for enrollment in a surgical program(30) Lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS), in which small wedges of damaged lung tissue are removed. The reduced space in the chest cavity may lead to a more physiologic reconfiguration of the chest wall and diaphragm, helping the remaining lung tissue and diaphragm work more efficiently(8,30) In a cohort of 1,078 patients from the National Emphysema Treatment Trial in the United States, patients with emphysema who received LVRS were compared to patients who received medical intervention only. At 24 months, PaO 2 was reported to be increased and oxygen requirements decreased in the group that received LVRS(9) Patients undergoing maximal medical therapy plus LVRS were found to have improved health-related  QOL and gained more qualityadjusted  life years compared with maximal medical therapy alone in a prospective randomized clinical trial in the United States that involved 1,218 patients with severe emphysema(32) The significant differences were maintained until the sixth year Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction is an alternative to LVSR that is in later-stage clinical trials(30) This involves placement of one-way  expiratory valves or occluders, intended to cause collapse of the target area Injection of sealants into the peripheral airways to seal subsegmental target regions and eventually lead to airway collapse and atelectasis can also be used to reduce lung volume in select patients and target sites(30) Bronchoscopic coil treatment is a treatment to achieve lung volume reduction by placement of coils(33) A meta-analysis  of four independent European clinical trials showed that coil treatment improves pulmonary function, 6MWT distance, and QOL in patients with severe emphysema up to 1 year after treatment, independent of the distribution of the disease Lung transplantation for severe cases(30)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Medications prescribed may include bronchodilator drug therapy for coughing, shortness of breath (SOB), and difficulty breathing to open constricted airways(3) inhaled steroid treatments to ease the symptoms of SOB and constricted air passages(1) antibiotics to treat acute respiratory infections that may occur in conjunction with emphysema(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
CT scan, perfusion scintigram, and chest X-ray(1)
Chest X-ray  may show hyperinflation, small heart, flat diaphragms, and bullous changes(1)
Emphysema subtypes may be detected on CT scan(29)
Lung tissue biopsy: This can be performed to check for levels of cellular death in the tissue, an indicator of emphysematous lungs(10,11)
Spirometry recommended to diagnose airflow obstruction in individuals with respiratory symptoms(27)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, etc.). Is a productive cough present? How often does the patient become out of breath?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Does the patient have sleep apnea? Does the patient use a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine at night? -Poor sleep quality is a common complication of emphysema(1) -Some patients desaturate only at night, so may need nocturnal supplemental oxygen only(1) -Does the patient sleep with head elevated? Orthopnea can be graded by number of pillows the patient uses
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., dizziness, chest tightness, chest pain, sudden SOB)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient use supplemental oxygen? Document parameters used. Does the patient have asthma? Is the patient a current smoker? Obtain results of recent PFTs where available. Document use and parameters of mechanical ventilation as indicated (4) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ____________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any history of pneumonia or other respiratory complications?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs); inquire about supplemental oxygen
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient employed? What is the nature of the work tasks? Does SOB limit the patient’s ability to fulfill any responsibilities? Does the patient participate in recreational sports or activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: How much activity can the patient complete without becoming short of breath? What ADLs are impaired by the patient’s condition?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, does the patient have difficulty going upstairs, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Document any barriers to independence in patient’s community

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight and calculate BMI. Increase in BMI is associated with severity of emphysema independent of sex, age, and smoking history(34)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale
The 6-minute  distance x body weight (6MWORK) may assist in evaluating status/outcomes and may be superior to the 6MWT alone according to a study involving 124 individuals with COPD(12)
The 2-minute  walk test had high test-retest  reliability and correlated highly with 6MWT in study of 45 patients with COPD(13)
Stair test: Measure level of exertion in response to ascending flights of stairs
Following endurance activities, perceived levels of SOB and retesting of pulmonary function measures may be used to monitor activity tolerance
On auscultation of the lungs, rhonchi, wheezing, coarse rales, and diminished breath sounds may be heard
Monitor vital signs before, during, and after activity
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse quality/strength/rateAssess body mechanics as indicatedAssess general mobility
observation inspection palpation includi: Check for barrel chest deformity and hypertrophy of accessory muscles. Watch for the use of accessory muscles of respiration, including neck, intercostals, or abdominals (forcing exhalation). Check for decreased breath sounds and slight cyanosis around lips and fingernail beds
In the patient with emphysema, dyspnea, accessory muscle use, and pursed-lip  breathing are frequent findings upon observation(1)
It is common for a person with emphysema to have a cachectic appearance coupled with a barrel chest(1)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess posture in sitting and standing, noting any asymmetries or excessive kyphosis –Does the patient adopt any specific positions to reduce dyspnea? –Leaning slightly forward in sitting and standing may help reduce SOB
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Complete a general ROM assessmentEvaluate ADLs as indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisV olumes checked can include total amount of air moved (forced vital capacity [FVC]) and amount of air moved after 1 second of forced exhalation (forced expiratory volume in 1 second [FEV 1])(7) –Pulse oximetry to measure oxygen saturation levels –Auscultate all lung fields

other: The clinician must obtain physician orders concerning oxygen use and parameters during rehabilitation

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients may have SOB and increased fatigue, leading to decreased physical capacity
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out  (1) Cardiac disease, including right heart failure Asthma Respiratory acidosis Interstitial lung disease Anemia Pulmonary embolism  Acute viral infection Sleep apnea
prognosis: The patient’s age and FEV 1 after use of bronchodilator are the most important predictors of prognosis(1)

The BODE index may be used to predict mortality in COPD patients(15) –The BODE index is based on findings from an original group of 207 patients (in which 25 deaths occurred) -B = BMI = 1 point if 21 or less -O = degree of airflow obstruction = 1 point if FEV 1 50–64%  predicted, 2 points if 36–49%  predicted, 3 points if 35% predicted or less -D = degree of dyspnea = MMRC dyspnea scale derivation with 0–3 points given, 3 points if too breathless to leave home or breathless during dressing or undressing -E = exercise capacity (6MWT) = 1 point if 250–349 meters, 2 points if 150–249  meters, 3 points if < 150 meters –The BODE index was validated in a prospective cohort of 625 COPD patients with 26% mortality (61% deaths due to respiratory insufficiency) -Overall survival decreased with increasing BODE score: mean BODE score was 3.7 among survivors vs. 5.9 among nonsurvivors, and a BODE score of 7–10  was associated with 80% mortality at 52 months
Supplemental oxygen where indicated increases survival(1)
Smoking cessation is important for improved prognosis(1)
Prognosis is negatively affected by the number of comorbidities –Malnutrition, corpulmonale, hypercapnia, and pulse > 100 indicate a poor prognosis(1)

Obvious emphysematous changes seen on CT during an acute exacerbation of COPD predicts a poor prognosis independent of other known predictors(35) –Based on a study that followed up on 106 patients who had CTs performed during an emergency department visit for an acute exacerbation of COPD –Emphysematous changes were quantified by measuring the percentage of low-attenuation  areas in the entire lung on CT images. Other factors that could influence prognosis were also recorded and analyzed
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Speech therapy and respiratory therapy for advanced airway clearance techniques Smoking cessation program Nutritionist Chest physical therapy Pulmonology Nursing for proper inhaler use
other considerations: In patients with emphysema, anxiety is associated with decreased exercise capacity and reduced QOL(16) –Based on cohort of 1,828 patients with moderate-severe emphysema enrolled in National Emphysema Treatment Trial (NETT) –Among these patients, there were significant associations between anxiety and -reduced exercise capacity -decreased QOL -increased SOB
treatment summary: Guidelines published by the American College of Physicians, American College of Chest Physicians, American Thoracic Society, and European Respiratory Society (ACP/ACCP/ATS/ERS) and guidelines of GOLD are in agreement that pulmonary rehabilitation should be considered for all patients with functional impairment due to symptoms of COPD(27,28) –ACP/ACCP/ATS/ERS guidelines recommend that pulmonary rehabilitation be provided for symptomatic patients with an FEV 1< 50% and considered for symptomatic or exercise-limited  patients with an FEV 1> 50% predicted. GOLD guidelines recommend that all patients who develop SOB when walking at their own pace on level ground be offered rehabilitation(27,28)

Pulmonary rehabilitation improves dyspnea and fatigue level while enhancing the individual’s perception of control surrounding health status(17) –Based on a systematic review including a total of 20RCTs –Improvements in outcome measures were clinically significant, although improvement in exercise capacity was modest

Comprehensive pulmonary rehabilitation improved exercise performance and symptoms, but benefits waned over time(18) –Based on an RCT conducted in the United States –One hundred nineteen outpatients with stable moderate to severe COPD were randomized to comprehensive pulmonary rehabilitation program vs. education program for 8 weeks –The rehabilitation group had significantly larger improvements in -maximal exercise tolerance -maximal oxygen uptake -exercise endurance -symptoms of perceived breathlessness -muscle fatigue -self-efficacy  for walking –Participants were followed for 6 years; benefits of rehabilitation appeared to wane after 1 year; no differences in general QOL were noted

Pulmonary rehabilitation was shown to have some benefit at 1 year in disabled patients(19) –Based on an RCT conducted by researchers from the United Kingdom –Two hundred individuals with disabling chronic lung disease (most with COPD) participated in the study –Subjects were randomized to a 6-week  multidisciplinary rehabilitation program (18 visits) vs. standard medical management –Follow-up  at 1 year demonstrated -no significant difference in 40% hospitalization rate -that the average number of days (10.4 vs. 21) spent in the hospital did differ significantly -that the rehabilitation group also had superior gains in walking ability and disease-specific  health status

A comprehensive pulmonary rehabilitation program lasting 6 months led to significant gains, observed in various outcome measures, which remained at 18-month  follow-up(20) –Based on a randomized trial involving 100 patients with a diagnosis of severe COPD –The trial was conducted by researchers from Belgium –Patients were randomized to either the rehabilitation group (cycling, walking, and strength training) or standard medical

improved respiratory function through br: Physical capacity prior to SOB or amount of activity the patient is able to complete
Repeat measures of respiratory volumes compared to measurements prior to treatment

maintenance or prevention: Removal/decreased exposure to environmental and or chemical pollutants, including smoking cessation or avoidance of chemical exposure(3)
Early detection via PFTs in high-risk  patients may help preserve remaining lung function(1)
Completion of the respiratory exercise at home(3)
Use of pharmacological agents, as directed(3)
Regular exercise and clearance of airway passages(26)
Protection from cold air and respiratory infections(26)
